text: Fourth of July weekend. The dock crammed with PEOPLE AND VEHICLES -- rows of cars, RV's and trucks in line to boar the Sea Bride, a huge PASSENGER FERRY. It's clearly the Fourth: flags tied to cars and strollers ice cream and picnic baskets, scores of FAMILIES with cam around their necks and kids in tow. A young girl, JANICE, looks down over the railing.
Mommy, I lost my doll ... The young girl's mother, BETH, pulls her away from the ra

Don't worry, baby, we'll get you another one. FERRY WORKERS wave a military transport vehicle into the deck through an open BOW DOOR. Other cars follow -- EXT. FERRY — FORWARD SUN DECK - DAY A group of ELDERLY VETERANS with potbellies and thick gla greet several YOUNGER, LONG-HAIRED VETS with hugs and backslaps. A sign reads:

head_text.subj: DEFENDING OUR COUNTRY, SERVING OUR COMMUNITY.

text: Behind them, the sun deck fills with holiday passengers. KINDERGARTNERS crowd the rail with their harried TEACHER, eager kids on a summer field trip.
The weatherworn FERRY CAPTAIN scans the harbor with cauti eyes. Behind him, the PILOT glances at the ship's clock.
Five minutes past the hour, sir.  2. The Captain nods. The Pilot SOUNDS THE HORN, throttles up
The Sea Bride cuts a wide wake as it churns past the Orie Point Lighthouse. As the ferry passes, we might notice a LONE FIGURE at the base of the lighthouse, watching the ship as it departs .
Well underway, the ferry passes a COAST GUARD CUTTER. The cutter's crew waves to the holiday crowd; ferry passenger wave back. A FANFARE STRIKES --

A NAVY BAND -- two dozen sailors in dress whites -- plays John Philip Sousa tune for the passengers. Above them han banner, ‘WELCOME SUBASE NEW LONDON FAMILIES!' Nearby, a MAN IN A WHEELCHAIR sits next to a KID INA STROLLER, both of them asleep. The young mother, Beth, hoists Janice up on her shoulders a better look at the band. Janice laughs, delighted, the doll forgotten -—-

FILLED WITH PEOPLE -- reading, playing cards, scolding th kids, eating hot dogs. INT. CAR DECK — DAY Over a hundred vehicles parked end-to-end, on two levels along the hull and down four center lanes. A FERRY WORKER leans against a school bus, catching a smoke on the sly. All's quiet down here. Then, from somewhere forward, a CAR RADIO starts --

(filtered) It's ten forty-eight on Endless Summer Sunday ... now let's go back in time to 1964 and the Beach Boys! On Long Island's 98 FM!! The opening chords of the Beach Boys' 'Don't Worry, Baby' echo in the chamber, sounding almost ghostly. The Ferry Worker looks annoyed -- some idiot is going to a dead battery. He walks toward the sound ...  3. A WHITE FORD EXPLORER sits parked on the second level hul ramp, its RADIO BLARING as the worker approaches.

(filtered) Well, it's been building up inside of me for, oh I don't know how long ... I don't know why, but I keep thinkin’ Somethin's bound to go wrong ... The Worker cups his hands over his eyes, peers into the passenger window -- that's weird -- No keys in the igni ti one He walks around the back, checks the license number, frow The plate's been removed. Weirder. He glances in through the back window -- FOUR ORANGE BARRELS inside. He ponders that for a moment. Because a moment is all he has ...
But she looks in my eyes ... and makes me re-a-lize when she says -- THE EXPLOSION tears through him so fast we don't even see pieces, just WHITE DEATH BLASTING OUT IN ALL DIRECTIONS -

The FLOOR ERUPTS UNDER THE CROWD, obliterating the band, passengers, Beth and Janice on her shoulders, everyone -- INT. CAR DECK — DAY The blast punches through the hull like a shotgun charge, BLOWING THE FORWARD CAR RAMP CLEAR OFF ITS HYDRAULICS and over the Sound. The gaping bow is open to RUSHING SEAWATE BURNING CARS are swamped by the sudden tide -- THE CAR DE
The entire ship lurches downward, the ship's prow digging into the blue waters as her main fuel tanks rupture --

head_text.subj: -- AND THE ENTIRE FERRY, ALL FOUR STORIES OF HER, IS BLAS

text: APART IN A CATACLYSMIC EXPLOSION. Huge chunks of hull, flaming deck panels, a thousand ragged fragments scatter the water in a sudden apocalypse.
Dust floats down through the water, followed by debris, t a car ... two cars, twelve cars, more ... the SONG still playing eerily as they pass ...
Don't worry, baby ... Don't worry, baby ... Everything will turn out all right ... More wreckage sinks, falling past us, a nightmare, until water turns black ...

Rain pours down. Frenzy and hysteria -- BODIES on stretch are carried from the Coast Guard cutter. RED CROSS and EM CRISIS TEAMS swarm the pier. NEWS CREWS dodge ambulance trucks -- SHRIEKING LOCALS push forward, begging CROWD CONTROL POLI for information --
-- we don't know yet, ma'am, please, we don't know --
My daughter's on that ferry, oh God my daughter! --

Just let us ask, maybe they're here, Maybe someone saw them -- PARAMEDICS pass by, revealing -- SPECIAL AGENT DOUG CARLIN standing next to a black sedan, motionless amid the chaos, indifferent to the rain. Mid-— thirties, a cold intelligence, Doug's eyes miss nothing: TWO POLICE DOGS, led by detectives, sniff at a broken, scorched life-preserver -- Doug's eyes shift. AMBULANCE WORKERS stand ready, but with nothing to do, helpless -- Doug registers this, eyes moving on. A pair of COAST GUARD CREWMEN try to console a group of N CADETS, several of whom are in tears. Doug looks past the Cadets -- near the dock, a SHELL-SHO WOMAN is standing alone, locking lost as the chaos swirls around her. Doug notices -- a WHITE SATELLITE VAN creeps along, comes a stop. It's marked BROOKHAVEN NATIONAL LABORATORY. Doug frowns --
Agent Minuti! Doug turns. Another agent, ANDREW PRYZWARRA, stands there notebook over his head against the rain.
Are you Larry Minuti? He steps toward Doug, smiling.
No. Larry is my partner.
Andy Pryzwarra, New York Field Office. Where’s Larry?
On vacation for the Fourth.
Not anymore. The Bureau's calling back half the eastern seaboard on this one. I'm sorry, your name?
Doug Carlin. Pryzwarra's smile fades.
Ah. Carlin, right. Evidence recovery. We need you back at the field office, and your partner if you can find him. Doug nods, continues scanning the area. Pryzwarra looks o
Quite a scene, huh? What are you looking for?
Anything that doesn't belong. Pryzwarra registers the rebuff. He looks out -- nearby, shell-shocked Woman is still standing alone, crying in th rain. Pryzwarra starts to move toward her:
Miss? Are you --
Don't.
I'm just -- I was going to get her a blanket or something.
Each of these people is a piece of evidence. And we don't touch evidence. Doug resumes his surveillance. Pryzwarra watches him.
Damn, that's cold.

It's not our job to care about these people. It's our job to catch the one who did this. The sudden muffled sound of a CELL PHONE. Both men turn - They're standing near a LINE OF BODIES laid out by paramedics. The cell phone RINGS AGAIN, inside one of the body bags. Never to be answered. Doug stares at it. Then he turns away, back toward his ca Pryzwarra stares at the body bag, cell phone still RINGIN

Jesus. DOUG'S SEDAN moves through the crime scene, passes by -—- A LARGE MAN in jeans and T-shirt stands at the open door the white Brookhaven van. He juggles a backpack, cell pho and umbrella. His name is GUNNARS. Gunnars opens his umbrella. Then extracts an odd-looking of high-tech night-vision style goggles from his backpack Gunnars puts them on, scans the area, looking this way an that, like some giant bug-eyed fish on land. He comes clo to CAMERA, talking into his cell phone, speaking low --

Nope. Empty. Totally empty. (beat) I don't see a soul ... He moves off ... and past him, of course, are cars, truck emergency workers yelling, victims' family members crying +e. the place is full of people.

Doug moves along amid a swirl of activity: ringing phones ANALYSTS and ASSISTANTS rushing between desks, the frenzy a crime unit in the wake of a national disaster. Doug's assistant, DONNELLY, falls in step alongside him.
Has Minuti called in yet?
He's not answering his cell, we left him a message at home -- Doug is already dialing his own cell phone. Donnelly hand him something:
-- and here's yours from last night. Say, did that girl ever get ahold of you? She sounded cute.
What girl?
(a beat, then he laughs) Right, right ... Donnelly walks away, smiling. Doug glances at the message
Whose number -- What is this, a candy wrapper? Donnelly!
(from Doug's phone) ‘This is Larry Minuti. I can't come to the phone now -- '' A SECRETARY waves from her desk:
Doug! Suffolk County on Line One, they pulled a body out of the water and want you to coordinate a profile!
(under his breath) Already ... (calling) Take a message, Kathy! (the phone beeps) Larry, it's Doug! Vacation's over, buddy. Get your ass in here, there's work to do.

CLOSE ON: Special Agent in Charge (SAC) JACK McCREADY, se at a crowded conference table. An imposing man, he reads loose pages, tough words coming from a gentle face -- McCREADY At approximately 10:50 this morning, the passenger ferry Sea Bride exploded in the waters of Long Island Sound, seven miles southwest of New London, Connecticut. Early estimates place the number of casualties at eight hundred and forty-three men, women and children. Shock and anger from those present. Doug enters at the ba unnoticed and unimportant. Standing room only, he looks o the shoulders of two taller agents to see -- McCREADY Men, ladies -- this happened on July Fourth. The Sea Bride was carrying servicemen and their families to a special event at Groton Sub Base. We consider this a deliberate act of terrorism against the United States Navy. The President concurs with our assessment. McCready shuffles to a new piece of paper -—- McCREADY Uh, I'm also told that someone claiming to be a Federal Agent stole an ambulance out of Brookhaven Medical last night. So whoever took it, just leave the keys on my desk, and there'll be no questions asked. Polite laughter from the room. Nice try, boss.  McCREADY Folks, this is a perfect act of terrorism. There were no baggage checks, no flight data recorders, maximum casualties, and all the evidence is under 90 feet of seawater. Don't overlook anything.
Doug is at his desk rushing through a phone message, cand wrapper in hand:
(into phone) This is Special Agent Doug Carlin returning your call, the number here is 516-753-0130 --

(calling out) Doug! Suffolk County on Line One again. They still need a profile for that floater -- DOUG. They don't need a profile, just have ‘em bag it and -- shit, never mind -- (he punches the line) Sheriff Reed?
(over the phone) Agent Carlin, I know you've got your hands full right now...
That's okay, tell me what you have.
Couple of kids found a woman face down in the water off Plum Island -- she's got burns over 80 percent of her body, just totally black --
You're gonna see a lot of that over the next few weeks, Sheriff. We're still setting up an E.c.c. Just have Crime Scene bag it for us and --
Already done. Body's on its way to the M.E. right now.  10.
It's on its -- ? (what? wait a minute ...) Crime Scene's already been there?
Been and gone. And now Doug gives this his full attention, because somet is definitely not right:
Sheriff ... exactly what time did this woman wash up on shore?
Kids called it in at ... Ten forty-two a.m.
You mean eleven forty-two.
No, ten forty-two. Got the sheet right in front of me, and got my reading glasses on, too. Doug ponders that for a moment. Then:
Which M.E.?

Sterile, metal, white. The MEDICAL EXAMINER leans over an autopsy table, eyes closed, almost in prayer. He whispers the form under the sheet: M.E. My name is Doctor Philip Vavala. Tell me. That ritual observed, he gently pulls the sheet away -- -- revealing the CHARRED BLUE BODY of a young WOMAN, wear what used to be a pretty summer dress. She stares up at u cold, angelic, dead. Doug stares at her, standing a few feet back. The M.E. gestures him closer, as if to say, 'come take a look.' Doug moves to the woman's side -- suddenly she turns to l straight into his eyes. The M.E. has rolled her head to o side.  11.

(into a hanging mike) This is the body of an adult female, Caucasian, in her late twenties or early thirties. Weight of the body is 78 pounds resident, 64 inches in length ... Doug stares at the dead woman's face, entranced. Her eyes are lifeless, skin pallid, lips bluer than ice. Under the circumstances she can't possibly be beautiful - but she once was. The kind of beauty that grows on you.

Immediately evident is heavy focal charring of the limbs and torso; anterior chest, face and neck are intact though swollen from apparent immersion in seawater. The M.E. glances along the woman's arm, down to her hands Frowns. Picks up a Polaroid camera. Indicates to Doug --

Would you hold that up for me please? Doug blinks -- who, me? He gingerly takes the woman's blackened hand, lifts it off the table. As the M.E. aims the camera, Doug looks down at the hand resting in his own: All five fingers have been sheared away, leaving ragged stumps. Doug looks away. Several FLASHES as the M.E. snaps photos

Each digit of the left hand has been severed between the middle and distal phalanges -- angle of shearing indicates a single sharp force trauma, possibly caused by shrapnel ... Doug looks back to the woman's face. He notices a SINGLE PEARL EARRING in one ear. He glances at her other ear -- pierced but empty.

«e+ posterior charring gives off a strong diesel odor, suggesting perimortem immersion in burning fuel.  12. An odd, hypnotic look comes over Doug -- almost as if he knows her. He brings his hand up to the Woman's face ... until the tips of his fingers rest softly on her lips. M.E. What are you doing? Doug doesn't seem to hear. He brings his fingers off the woman's mouth -- her lips stick lightly to his fingertips
What are you doing?

Do you have a UV gun? M.E. Second shelf behind you. Doug goes to the shelf. Intrigued now, the M.E. moves to head of the table, turns off the overhead lamp. Doug brings a hand-held ULTRAVIOLET GUN to the table. Aim at the woman's face, pulls the trigger -- -- illuminating a WIDE BAND OF CHEMICAL RESIDUE across he mouth and cheeks, glowing like yellow neon. The shape is perfect rectangle.
Duct tape ... Doug nods. They stare at the dead girl's mouth.

What's that stippling ... see that? He points: within the band of tape residue, numerous TRAC PARTICLES stand out under the light like tiny stars. The brings the magnifying lamp over, leans in for a closer lo M.E. Adhesive probably retained some substance against the seawater -- The woman's eyes suddenly sparkle; light spills across th body from an OPEN DOOR. A LOCAL COP steps in --

We may have a name. Missing Persons has a 'Claire Kuchever' reported missing this morning, when she didn't pick up her parents at JFK. The report's being faxed. Doug nods. Turns back to the body.  13.
Claire ...? No answer, of course.

Doctor, I want you to perform a full autopsy. Pretend you never heard about a ferry explosion -- concentrate on time and cause, full spread of lab tests, everything. M.E. Absolutely. Doug picks up the Polaroid camera, centers it on the woma face. He hesitates, looks at her almost apologetically .. Then aims the camera again, holds it there. A FLASH --
Wood porch, nice lawn, mailbox by the fence. The rain has become a constant drizzle, a grey tarp over the scene. Doug sits in his car, looking out at the house, reluctant

A SHRIEK of pure grief. CLAIRE'S MOTHER is crying hysterically; CLAIRE'S FATHER rocks and hushes her, weepi himself. They cling to each other on the couch. On the coffee table in front of them rests the Polaroid p of their daughter, dead on an autopsy table. Doug picks up the photograph, waits quietly as Claire's parents try to cope.
OH GOD! I was so mean to her on the phone! Oh Claire! I'm sor-ry ...
No-no-no, shh, shhhh ...

It can't be. It can't. It can't ... Doug looks away, uncomfortable, focusing on the decor. Hi gaze comes to rest on several framed photographs on the Mantle. He notices one in particular -- A PHOTO of a young woman: CLAIRE KUCHEVER. Pretty hair, a beautiful smile. The kind of beauty that grows on you.  14.
(realizing) The ferry disaster. She was on the ferry. Oh, God.
We don't know yet, sir. But anything you can tell me about your daughter's activities this weekend will help.

(barely hanging on) I don't know, she -- she was supposed to meet us this morning, we've been away all week -- when her car was gone, we thought maybe she sold it -- she'd been trying to for awhile --
She lives alone?
Yes -- her fiancé broke up with her in March. She wanted kids, but he didn't.
(barely audible) She had a date ...
What?
(sits up, sniffling) A blind date. Last night, on the phone, she told me, she was going to go out. On a date. In Connecticut. Her friend Beth set it up.
Beth?
Beth Harris. Doug nods, mental note made.
Claire babysits her daughter, Janice, during the week sometimes ... Oh God! And she breaks again, weeping convulsively. Her husband h her, giving what comfort he can.  15.
We'll, ah ... we'll need a recent photo, and keys to her house if you have them. They don't hear him anymore, lost in naked grief. Doug wa profoundly uncomfortable. Finally:
Someone will be in touch. He gets up to leave.
Doug comes through the door -- suddenly Claire's father reaches for his arm.
Mister Carlin?
Doug, please. You can call me Doug.

Listen ... Doug... (he struggles for words) Claire ... wrote funny poems in her Christmas cards. She loved Cary Grant movies. She used to dance with her cat sometimes, she named it Ginger, you can guess why. (a plea) I know how these things go, but please -.. I need her to matter to you. Doug blinks, motionless. Claire's Father hands him a photograph -- the one from the mantle -- and a set of key Doug looks at them. A wail of anguish from inside and Dou lecks up -- and meets the eyes of Claire's Father. The door closes.

Still light out, but barely. Doug stares through the windshield out at a tree-lined street, a quaint one-story house. The driveway is empty. Doug pulls a pair of plastic gloves out of his pocket and gets out of his car, approaches the house.  16.

A key turning in the lock. Doug pushes the door, lets it and looks into the house, not stepping inside. There, as if to greet him, standing in the center of a carpet, is a CAT with black and white fur.

Hello, Ginger. The cat steps forward ... then suddenly leaps up into Dou arms; he has no choice but to catch it. Doug is startled a moment, not sure what to do. Then shru steps inside, scratching the cat's head. He looks around The decor is feminine, inviting, furnished with antiques thoughtfully rescued from thrift shops and farmers' marke Doug sees an ANSWERING MACHINE by the door, light blinkin He sets the cat down, pulls a pen from his pocket, uses i press PLAY. Walks through the room as the TAPE REWINDS.

Hi Claire, this is Helen French at Pennylane Books. We're putting together a Language Arts series for grades K through 8, and I'd like to see if you would do some illustrations for us! Give me a call! Doug comes to Claire's work area. Pages rest on the table ORIGINAL COLOR DRAWINGS of kids at a playground, a day at circus, a schoolyard. One drawing stands out: a color rendering of an EIGHT-YEAR-OLD GIRL with braids.

Hi, Claire, it's Dad. Our flight gets in at 8:05 tomorrow morning -- your mother asked me to remind you, don't stay out too late ... thanks, bye. Doug grimaces. Moves to the fireplace -- next to it is a basket full of dolls (same type as the one we saw floatin face down in the water). A BEEP, then a hang-up. Doug kneels to examine the toys. Glances into the fireplace ... and sees A SINGLE SHEET OF LAVENDER STATIONERY burned up in there, one corner intact He touches the corner with his pen.  17. Another BEEP, another hang-up. Doug looks up, and the cat leaps out of his arms, races to the kitchen. Another BEEP

(concerned) Claire? Hi, it's Beth, are you there? I'm sorry to call so late, but you said you were going to call me when you got home, and when you didn't, I started to get worried -- -- there's the 'click' of someone picking up the phone:
Is this a joke? Doug frowns -— she sounds distressed --
What? No! I was worried about you, that's all. How'd the date go --
I can't talk right now, someone's here. I'll call you tomorrow.
Claire -- ! The hang-up cuts Beth off in mid-sentence. Doug goes to t machine, hits REWIND, then PLAY again:
Is this a joke?
What? No! I was worried about you, that's all. How'd the date go --
I can't talk right now, someone's here. I'll call you tomorrow.
Claire -- ! Doug hits STOP. He looks away, thinking. Suddenly there i very loud MEOW from the kitchen. Doug smiles --

Doug walks in, notices: on the table, TWO GLASSES, filled with water.  18. Ginger, the cat, is on the counter. She bumps a rather ab locking tomato-shaped cooking timer. Rubs up against a particular cabinet. Using a gloved hand, Doug opens the cabinet. Cat food. Of course. He drops a handful of cat food into a dish for th starving cat. Turns to the refrigerator -- A CHILD'S CRAYON DRAWING is affixed to the door; we can m out the words 'JANICE HARRIS, Gr. 2' scrawled at the bott Next to it: a newspaper ad for a 'White FORD EXPLORER, lo miles, excellent condition.' Doug glances up -- the freezer door is littered with word from a magnetic poetry kit. In the middle, a sentence:
Doug stares at the words. Pulls out his notebook --

Doug looks in, notebook in hand. He surveys the room. The is made but crumpled, as if somebody fell onto it. He ste in -- and something CRUNCHES under his foot. Looks down: SHATTERED PORCELAIN ON THE FLOOR. Doug kneels. DROPS OF B on the fragments. Doug looks back at the bed. Crumpled -- as if somebody fe onto it.
Doug starts the machine with his pen, takes notes as the of the MESSAGES play:

Claire, it's your mother. We've been waiting at the airport for forty minutes now. If you're not coming I hope you're sending Beth or someone --. call us. We read Doug's notes, one under the other: CAR MISSING. E FIANCE. BLIND DATE IN CT (FERRY?) LATE CALL, BETH HARRIS.
He adds: "SOMFONE'S HERE." Circles it, closes the pad. He for the hallway when he hears one last BEEP:

This is Special Agent Doug Carlin returning your call, the number here is 516-753 --  19. Doug spins in a hammer shock of disbelief. Then it comes him. He rips off one of his gloves, digs into his pocket -- and pulls out the CANDY WRAPPER WITH THE PHONE NUMBER WRITTEN ON IT. He holds the wrapper up to the machine, wi his gloved hand, presses the ANNC button:

Hello! This is 462-8423. I'm sorry I missed your call, but if you say something nice, I'll call you back! The number on the wrapper is 462-8423. BEEP, CLICK, silen Doug stands in the middle of the room, staring at the dea girl's telephone.
Wreckage on the water, rotors in the night. SEARCH AND RE HELICOPTERS sweep the floating debris with searchlights. A CRANE lifts a submerged CAR from the sea --

TELEVISION NEWS CREWS make their reports from a long row satellite vans. A troop truck carrying NAVY DIVE TEAM mem rolls past the giant hangar -- -- and past DOUG, who stands outside staring at the doors hesitating for some reason. He takes a deep breath -- onc twice -- then holds it and opens the door into --

A cavernous makeshift morgue. ROWS AND ROWS OF BODY BAGS lie across the floor awaiting identification; more are being laid out by FBI FORENSICS TEAMS. A harvest of death under black plastic. Doug marches past them, past a handful of POLICE and FAMI MEMBERS moving among the bodies, down the long center ais He passes a PERSONAL EFFECTS AREA: shredded backpacks, so purses, a child's blackened sneakers. He never breaks str doesn't look, keeps moving toward --

FBI CREWS and NTSB INVESTIGATORS have begun to reconstruc the ferry from recovered debris. A flatbed truck backs up bearing A HUGE SLICE OF HULL like a giant ragged melon ri  20. At a long table, several AGENTS -- McCready and Pryzwarra among them -- are gathered around a collection of small pieces of metal, none bigger than a quarter:
«+. Our early guess is that the bomb vehicle was a minivan or SUV. Possibly white or silver --
Make and model?
No way to tell yet.

Hey, I got a partial on the license plate ... All eyes turn to AGENT BROOKS -- he holds up a tiny slive metal with a pair of tweezers and smirks. A few tired groans at the gallows humor. McCready turns b to Stalhuth.
How long? Stalhuth looks over the debris.
Could be weeks. Months.
Check all SUVs and minivans registered in the state, anything recently rented or purchased, anything tied to a theft or missing persons report -—-
Agent McCready? McCready turns -- Doug is there.
I'm Agent Carlin, LIRA Evidence Recovery --
(cold) Douglas Carlin. I remember you. Flight 800 investigation. The other agents look up at that. Doug blanches, stands h ground. Pryzwarra wonders at their reaction, steps forwar  21.
Hello, Doug. You have something? Doug stares at the others, then to Pryzwarra:

This afternoon I witnessed the autopsy of a young woman who washed up off Plum Island, with heavy fuel burns and traces of thermite powder on her face. She‘d also lost several fingers in what appeared to be blast damage. McCready catches the slight inflection:
‘Appeared. '
When I checked the tide tables against the position of the blast ... sir, this woman was killed at least two hours before the ferry exploded.

Before? Doug turns to see a civilian approaching the table: ALEXA DENNY. Black T-shirt, tennis shoes, long wispy hair. Stan with the agents in their suits, he looks like a crazed ge scientist or an aging rock star.
You say she died before the explosion? Doug blinks -- who is this guy? -- then:
Her name is Claire Kuchever. Her body washed up before the explosion and against the tide. Doug has everyone's attention now. McCready is dubious, stares at him.
You have a scenario?
I believe someone abducted her from her home, taped her mouth and wrists, then severed her fingers -- probably because she had his DNA under her nails. (MORE)
DOUG (cont'd) Then he burned her alive and dumped her into the Sound, where she would appear to be just another disaster victim --
A disaster that hadn't happened yet.
(to Doug) You refer to the killer as ‘he.' Why not 'they?'

I work Evidence Recovery as needed. My main field is victimology. I believe we're looking for a lone individual, most likely a paranoid sociopath. No group has claimed responsibility? Pryzwarra shakes his head 'no.'
Why this woman?

Her SUV is missing. It could have been stolen to drive the bomb onto the ferry. (checks his file) New York license CHB 4470. A white Ford Explorer. The agents look down at the pieces, then at each other -- yeah, that fits. Doug holds out his report to McCready.
Something else ... The victim placed a call to the Long Island field office the night before she was killed. Denny's eyebrows go up at this. McCready takes the report

Thank you. We'll look into it. (Doug stands there) Thank you. Doug has been dismissed. He turns, walks away ... and not for the first time a row of cars parked against the far w Doug stops and calls back --
Hey, where's Minuti?
What?  23. Doug indicates a particular car, parked down the line: bl early model BMW. Boston Red Sox cap visible through the b window. A bumper sticker: WHITE CANE POST 56.
My partner, Larry Minuti. That's his car. Pryzwarra looks ... then closes his eyes in an ‘aw, fuck’ expression. Even McCready looks solemn.

Agent Carlin ... those cars were brought here from the ferry parking lot. Vehicles that remain unclaimed. (a beat) I'm sorry. Doug stares at McCready as realization sinks in. He looks the other agents ... none of them can meet his eyes. Doug turns. Walks away, between the rows of bodies. Denny watches him leave, thoughtful.
May I see that report?
Doug leans on the driver's side window of his car, head d not moving. In the glass, the distorted reflection of an HELICOPTER moves past. Doug closes his eyes.
Agent Carlin? Doug opens his eyes. Reflected in the glass are now the distorted shapes of two MILITARY POLICE OFFICERS. Doug turns. One is tall and muscular. The other short and even more muscular.
Would you come with us, please? Doug regards them. They're serious, there to do a job.
I have a choice? The MP cracks a smile.
As a matter of fact, sir, no, you don't.  24.

Doug sits in a straight-back chair in front of an empty d Looks like he's been there a while. The room is dominated on one side by a long TWO-WAY MIRRO Doug stares at it. The mirror seems to stare back. The door opens. Pryzwarra enters, sits down.
I'd guess you've got some questions.
For me to have questions, first I'd have to know something. Pryzwarra grins.
I've been put in charge of a newly created special investigative unit. Our first case is the ferry bombing. I want you on the team.
Why me?
You know the area. We need someone local, who also has the proper security clearance. Doug nods at the two-way mirror.
That's what you told the people back there. Why me? Pryzwarra smiles, leans forward.

I'm a good field agent. But this investigation has ... unique requirements. We need someone who can take exactly one look at a crime scene and tell us what's wrong, what's missing, what we can ignore and what we should pursue. Doug frowns. The mirror is still a strong, silent presenc Pryzwarra lowers his voice.
They won't say it, but you impressed the hell out of somebody.  25.
They told you my history?
I'm not worried about that. (beat) Can't change the past, right?
Streaking over miles of thick forest, crossing the Long Island Pine Barrens.
DOUG stares out the window, seated between two MPs, silen Pryzwarra sits across from him. Suddenly:
